definitions.definition: to become different

examples.text: Rick hasn't changed. He looks exactly the same as he did at school.
We examined changing attitudes towards education.
The company failed to adapt to **changing circumstances**.
Things have **changed dramatically** since then.
Her life changed completely when she won the lottery.
My attitude to life has changed with age.
Social attitudes are changing fast.
Her voice changed subtly.
Jane has changed a lot since she went to college.
Our way of life has changed dramatically over the last ten years.
The language is changing all the time.
The place had changed out of all recognition.
The town has actually changed very little in the last hundred years.

definitions.definition: to make somebody/something different

examples.text: Fame hasn't really changed him.
That experience **changed my life**.
The internet has changed the way people work.
Technology has changed the way people work.
It can be hard to get people to change their habits.
Technology has forever changed the way businesses operate.
This incident changed the whole course of events.

definitions.definition: to pass from one state or form into another; to make somebody/something pass from one state or form into another
definitions.sensetop: change from A to/into Bchange to/into somethingchange A to/into Bchange somebody/something from A to/into B

examples.text: Wait for the traffic lights to change.
The lights changed from red to green.
The lights changed to green.
Caterpillars change into butterflies.
With a wave of her magic wand, she changed the frog into a handsome prince.
He managed to change the mood from tense to relaxed in minutes.
examples.contextForm: change somebody/something from A to/into B

examples.text: Caracas changed from a small town into a busy city.
His anger changed to sadness.

definitions.definition: to stop having one state, position or direction and start having another

examples.text: Leaves change colour in autumn.
The wind has changed direction.
Our ship changed course.
The fruit changes colour as it ripens.

definitions.definition: to replace one thing, person, service, etc. with something new or different
definitions.sensetop: change somebody/somethingchange A for Bchange A to B

examples.text: I want to change my doctor.
I didn't **change my name** when I got married.
That back tyre needs changing.
We change our car every two years.
The law was changed in 2001.
Don't change the subject!
We changed the car for a bigger one.
She decided not to change her name to his.

definitions.definition: to exchange positions, places, etc. with somebody else, so that you have what they have, and they have what you have

examples.text: At half-time the teams change ends.
We asked the waiter if we could change tables.
Can I change seats with you?

definitions.definition: to exchange money into the money of another country

examples.text: I need to change some euros.
to change dollars into yen

definitions.definition: to exchange money for the same amount in different coins or notes

examples.text: Can you change a £20 note?
The storekeeper changed my dollar bill for four quarters.

definitions.definition: to exchange something that you have bought for something else, especially because there is something wrong with it; to give a customer a new item because there is something wrong with the one they have bought

examples.text: This shirt I bought's too small—I'll have to change it for a bigger one.
Of course we'll change it for a larger size, Madam.
If you bring the dress back with the receipt, you can change it.

definitions.definition: to go from one bus, train, etc. to another in order to continue a journey

examples.text: Where do I have to change?
Change at Reading (for London).
I stopped in Moscow only to change planes.

definitions.definition: to put on different or clean clothes
definitions.sensetop: change into somethingchange out of somethingchange something

examples.text: I went into the bedroom to change.
She changed into her swimsuit.
You need to change out of those wet things.
I didn't have time to **change clothes** before the party.
I didn't have time to **get changed** before the party *(= to put different clothes on)*.

definitions.definition: to put clean clothes or a clean nappy on a baby

examples.text: She can't even change a nappy.
The baby needs changing.
There are baby changing facilities in all our stores.

definitions.definition: to put clean sheets, etc. on a bed

examples.text: to change the sheets
Could you help me change the bed?

definitions.definition: to pass to a different owner

examples.text: The house has changed hands several times.

definitions.definition: to change to a different or new activity while you are in the middle of something else; to change from supporting one person or thing to another
to change a decision or an opinion

examples.text: Nothing will make me change my mind.
What made you change your mind?

definitions.definition: to be in somebody else’s situation

examples.text: I'm perfectly happy—I wouldn't change places with anyone.

definitions.definition: to express a different opinion or behave in a different way when your situation changes

examples.text: Wait until it happens to him—he'll soon change his tune.

definitions.definition: to start to live or behave in a different way from before

examples.text: He was in trouble with the police as a teenager but now he’s completely changed his ways.
Your father is unlikely to change his ways now.

definitions.definition: to keep changing your mind or what you are doing
people cannot change their character, especially if they have a bad character

examples.text: You didn’t really expect her to be on time, did you? A leopard can’t change its spots.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French change (noun), changer (verb), from late Latin cambiare, from Latin cambire ‘barter’, probably of Celtic origin.
